relationships.narrativeNotes: Ego consciousness is expanded through shadow integration.
Owning shadow material is a pivotal individuation movement.
Shadow material commonly appears in experience through projection.
Projection links personal perception with collective symbolic patterns.
Relational eros contributes to symbolic union.
Discerning logos contributes to symbolic union.
The Self acts as telos and ordering center.
Archetypal images mediate approach to totality.
The Self-symbol is often imaged through a fourfold structure that includes excluded opposites.
Fish motifs can represent aeonic transitions in collective symbolism.
Mandala imagery frequently symbolizes the Self as a centered totality.
Fourfold mandala structures image quaternity as psychic wholeness.
The cross serves as a central Christian symbol associated with the Christ image.
Astrological symbolism can represent long-period aeonic structures in collective imagination.
The fish motif functions as an emblem of the chapter's layered fish symbolism.
Ouroboric images recur in alchemical contexts as emblems of cyclical transformation.
The lapis motif represents the idea of the philosopher's stone as achieved transformation.
Shadow encounter anticipates integrative work.
Transformation themes culminate in completion motifs.
Fish symbolism holds paradoxical totality imagery.
Ouroboric images symbolize the containment and return of opposites.
The lapis expresses the coniunctio as completed opus.
